commitResults.messageBody: There are several methods to display the greeting exit messages. I have decided to store the greetings message and exit message as separate strings "header" and "ending". This improves the formatting of the code and makes future edits easier.
Create a UserInputHandler class that will handle the logic for reading user input and generating appropriate responses.

UserInputHandler uses Scanner object from java.util to communicate with user. Scanner object is initialised when UserInputHandler() constructor is called.

UserInputHandler logic has two basic methods getInput() and handleInput() to receive input from the user and to handle the input from the user.

Friday creates UserInputHandler object to handle user input when Friday is being used.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add BotMessage class, added BotMessage to Friday logic and added basic chatting logic
commitResults.messageBody: Used BotMessage class to encapsulate a bot response from Friday. Created a method start() in Friday to start a chat with a user. The chat ends only when the user inputs the String "bye". This is the intended behaviour of Level 1.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add basic list functionality to chatbot
commitResults.messageBody: Add ArrayList field to Friday which will store the inputs of the user. Add printlist() method to Friday which handles the logic for generating the string responsible for displaying the stored user inputs when user prompts the bot with "list". Adjusted start() logic to handle the prompt "list". Added additional String formatting to handleInput() in UserInputHandler.java.

Task class encapsulates the user input by storing the task description and an additional boolean field to determine the status of the Task. Add markAsDone() and markAsUndone() methods to change the isDone state. Change ArrayList in Friday to store Task objects instead. Add mark and unmark user input logic to start() in Friday.
Add Todo class. Testing SourceTree push changes.
Add Deadline and Event classes. Testing Git settings again.
Deadline, Event and Todo classes inherit from Task class.

commitResults.messageTitle: Modify start() logic to work with new Task subclasses and improved bot response
commitResults.messageBody: Use indexOf() and substring() methods to extract text from user input assuming that the user gives Friday an appropriate response. Use trim() to remove any additional whitespaces after the input description. This streamlines editing for the bot response.

commitResults.messageTitle: Modify runtest.sh to work with Friday
commitResults.messageBody: Changed file destinations to use runtest.sh script. Additionally, added spacings and "\t" tab spaces to beautify Friday's messages.

commitResults.messageTitle: Exception handling for Todo and Incorrect input
commitResults.messageBody: Add exception handling for Todo and incorrect inputs. Will add exception tests to scripts.sh and also add more exception handling to reach typical and stretch goals level.

Added delete command which deletes an entry according to the index of the Task in the list. For future reference, add exception handling for when trying to remove an item which is out of bounds of the array length (1, list.size()).

Tweak the usage of TodoException to a more generalised DescriptionException class as all 3 current Task subclasses contain a description and can be given an invalid description. Added a DeadlineException class to handle invalid deadlines after /by command. Finally, added logic to handle invalid description and invalid deadline given to a deadline command. Additionally, segmented the code in handleInput() for future reference using simple comments.

Add 3 exceptions to handle 3 different invalid inputs. MissingCommandException for missing /from and /to commands. FromException and ToException ensures that there is no empty inputs for those fields. Tweaked the logic of reading a deadline task to conform with MissingCommandException.

Added basic exception handling for delete command which resolves invalid inputs to a delete command, trying to delete an item from an empty list and also trying to delete an item which does not exist in the list.

Changed if else logic to use enums instead. Using enums allows the usage of switch case which improves readability and maintainability of the code base compared to if else statements. Moved printList() method to UserInputHandler as it made sense that UserInputHandler should provide this feature instead of Friday. Finally, moved more input cases into UserInputHandler.

Friday saves Tasks into a .txt file. Previous entries into the list is also recorded and loaded when Friday runs again. Storage class handles the saving of Tasks in the .txt file. Storage contains two methods, loadTasks() and saveTasks(). loadTasks() allows previously logged tasks to be recorded and used. saveTasks() allows new entries to be added and removed from the list, while being logged into the .txt file. Added logic to all subclasses of Task and Task to facilitate loadTasks().

Friday now understands and is able to interpret some formatted string inputs utilising java.time.LocalDateTime and java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter. Developers can change accepted formats in the FORMATTERS array in DateTimeParser.java. Friday also accepts a new command known as DATE. A DATE command takes in one of the accepted formatted string inputs and returns a list of deadline or event tasks that need to be done by the string input date.

HandleUserInput renamed to Parser for better understandability. Ui class is now responsible for reading user inputs and also responding to user inputs via System.out in the terminal. TaskList abstraction to encapsulate the original ArrayList<Task> to store the list of tasks. Storage class now receives a filepath String in its constructor, increasing usability.

Added further abstraction by encapsulating user input processing to an abstract command class. Commands can be executed using execute(), which handles the logic to add a task to the TaskList, handles exceptions if any and also returns a ui output via the terminal. This simplifies the Parser class, increasing readability.
Segmented classes and subclasses into various packages following addressbook-level2 as guideline. Added relevant import statements into file headers so that code functions with new file structure.
Achieved basic JUnit testing for Friday. Tested successfully TodoTest. Used stubs to test successfully ParserTest.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add JavaDoc to all non-trivial methods
commitResults.messageBody: JavaDoc has been added to all non-trivial methods in all classes.
Fixed import statements to conform to Java coding standard.
Added FindCommand class to execute a keyword search on the tasks in the project.
Followed javafx-tutorial to add basic working GUI to Friday.

Made a small adjustment to how error messages are displayed in Friday GUI. Changed the indentation for GUI to be consistent to other GUI message bubbles from Friday. Made a small adjustment to the ui/Friday class such that the text UI for Friday still works as intended.
Basic assertions to ensure that exceptions caused by user mis-inputs are handled appropriately in the logic of creating Task classes.
Add assertions to Friday

commitResults.messageTitle: Ensure code quality standards are met
commitResults.messageBody: Enforce SLAP and prominent code throughout codebase. Moved some variables for better readability.
Changed findTasks to implement java Streams.
A-Streams
A-CodeQuality

commitResults.messageTitle: Improve runtest and Friday GUI logic
commitResults.messageBody: Encountered issues during CI integration which led to the discovery that there were testing issues with runtest.sh script. After noticing issues with the runtest.sh script, noticed another mistake in the the way Friday GUI was loading tasks. It has been fixed and should be working as intended. Additionally, added the missing welcome message to Friday GUI.
A-CI increment

Added priority command to Friday's available commands. Every task now contains a field which indicates the priority of a task. H stands for high, M stands for medium and L stands for low.

The priority command requires an index (according to the index shown in the TaskList) and a relevant priority field after the /lvl command to assign a priority to a task.
C-Priority increment
